pr_title: Runwith implementation - load user info considering default, component, and recipe and resolve which user to run as at execution time

timeline.message:
Implement RunWith for user and group

Look up a default RunWith in the DeviceConfiguration

Lookup RunWith per deployed component

Allow running steps as a privileged user

Keep track of the info used to start a service so that after a deployment, the same user that started the service will stop it

Add integration tests
Remove enableLogBash flag and always enable
Remove reference to logbash in comment
Add windows test that ignores posix user/group

timeline.bodyText: use a try-finally to remove the listener at the end.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText:
[nit]
You could use a parameterized test for these
timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: windows shell too? powershell vs. cmd?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
so this makes it interesting - with linux shells, they all take a "-c" arg to pass a command to run
PowerShell is a completely different beast to cmd.exe and it takes a  "-Command" option rather than "/C", and has a ton of other parameters that customers may want to use
I'd prefer to attack this in a follow-on as there may be some powershell capabilities we wish to use - it supports a more straightforward way of running as a different user (although still requiring credentials)
It may be the case that for windows we require them to specify "cmd" or "powershell" as an enumeration and we figure out what to do based on that.
replies.author: rbattle

timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: why save to local vars and then the fields? Why not just write to the fields?
timeline.author: MikeDombo
MikeDombo
MikeDombo

timeline.bodyText: why only linux? Why not mac?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
These won't work unless your mac allows unknown users - which ours by default don't - and I don't want to require everyone to have to set up a test user in order to pass these tests.
I could make these enabled on mac and have them skip like I do in other tests by checking a similar sudo command
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: I've enabled the tests on mac - they'll skip on our laptops though
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: Why would it skip for us if you've enabled it
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
because we can't sudo to an unknown user - the assumeCanSudoShell method checks that we can execute sudo on a shell as a user 123456. If it cannot, the assumption fails, and the test is skipped.
On our provided mac laptops, we cannot execute sudo -u \#123456 - it will fail with sudo: unknown user: #123456
However - I just discovered that the userid -2 is predefined on macs as an "unprivileged user". I'll update this test to use that user instead so that it will run as expected
replies.author: rbattle

replies.bodyText: nevermind - it still won't work - it requires the user to enter the password for sudo as non-root user in the same session that the test is run in.
replies.author: rbattle

timeline.author: MikeDombo

timeline.message: Fix binaryCompatibility to find causes not just at the class level
